results.headline: Serial Killer Returns With Zombies and Tarantulas

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Collection

results.summary_short: “The Collection” treads the familiar ground of the “Saw” franchise.

results.headline: Homicidal Santa

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Silent Night

results.summary_short: In “Silent Night,” a seasonal homicidal Santa chooses Christmas Eve to exterminate the naughtiest residents of a small Wisconsin town.

results.headline: A World War II Mission, Precisely Detailed

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shady Lady

results.summary_short: “Shady Lady” tells the story of an Australian bombing raid contending with storms, crashes and bad omens.

results.headline: A Veteran, Damaged by War, Is Befriended by an Evangelical Christian

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of New Jerusalem

results.summary_short: Will Oldham, in the film “New Jerusalem,” creates a haunting portrait of an evangelical Christian who has perhaps put too much faith in rote rituals.

results.headline: A Journey Through Decay

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Brothers

results.summary_short: Paul Fraser’s film, “My Brothers,” describes a road trip in a barely working van, in search of a link to a father.

results.headline: A Rowdy Tale, Told by Cellphone Cameras

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of King Kelly

results.summary_short: Andrew Neel’s “King Kelly,” filmed almost entirely on cellphone cameras, is a satire that follows a teenage stripper on a night of drugs and booze.

results.headline: One Bad Turn Deserves Another

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Killing Them Softly

results.summary_short: When a poker game is robbed, the thieves must pay: enter Brad Pitt, who stars, along with Richard Jenkins, James Gandolfini and Ray Liotta.

results.headline: An Unlikely Hero Rises, and So Do Suspicions

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dragon

results.summary_short: A man does such a good job foiling a small-town robbery, he attracts the attention of a detective and gangsters.

results.headline: A Place for the Hopeless to Spin Their Wheels

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Parked

results.summary_short: In Darragh Byrne’s first feature film, two men who live in their cars forge a human connection.

results.headline: Round Robin of Connubial Disappointment

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Certainty

results.summary_short: “Certainty” centers on a young couple navigating the mandatory Roman Catholic premarriage preparations.

results.headline: War and Famine Meet in a Chinese Province in the ’40s

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Back to 1942

results.summary_short: “Back to 1942” explores what happened when war met famine in China’s Henan province in 1942, a disaster that cost millions of lives.

results.headline: An Outsize Talent for Drums and Trouble

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beware of Mr. Baker

results.summary_short: “Beware of Mr. Baker” is Jay Bulger’s documentary about the star rock drummer Ginger Baker, of Cream and Blind Faith.

results.headline: A Close Circle of Friends With Plenty of History

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ex-Girlfriends

results.summary_short: “Ex-Girlfriends,” by Alexander Poe, follows a group of attractive young New Yorkers as they date and text — mostly one another.

results.headline: Six Israeli Spymasters on a Shadowy Past and a Dark Future

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Gatekeepers

results.summary_short: The documentary “The Gatekeepers” explores Israel’s history, present and future through the eyes of six former heads of the internal security agency Shin Bet.

results.headline: Damaged Souls, Trying to Heal, Learning to Survive

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rust and Bone

results.summary_short: In “Rust and Bone,” a muscular melodrama from Jacques Audiard, a woman who loses her legs in a whale attack finds emotional healing through a relationship with a rough boxer.

results.headline: A Knife and a Shower: Sounds Hitchcockian

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hitchcock

results.summary_short: “Hitchcock,” starring Anthony Hopkins, is based on a book about the making of the horror classic “Psycho.”

results.headline: When Innocence Meets the Opera
results.display_title: Gottfried Helnwein and the Dreaming Child

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gottfried Helnwein and the Dreaming Child

results.summary_short: The documentary “Gottfried Helnwein and the Dreaming Child” follows the painter of the title and his involvement in a production by the Israeli Opera.

results.headline: Filmmakers Still Seek Lessons From a Case That Rocked a City

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Central Park Five

results.summary_short: The documentary “The Central Park Five” is equal measures criminal investigation, cultural exhumation and a consideration of race in a presumptively postracial America.

results.headline: He’s Lost the Game. Can He Beat the Koreans?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Red Dawn

results.summary_short: In “Red Dawn,” a remake of the 1984 film, young people band together to fight North Koreans who have invaded Spokane, Wash.

results.headline: Plenty of Gods, but Just One Fellow Passenger

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Life of Pi

results.summary_short: “Life of Pi,” directed by Ang Lee and based on the novel by Yann Martel, features a young man, a tiger and lots of talk about God.
